albumData.title: 150908 Clear ice and ice ball experiments: moving water, "Japanese pond" slow freezing, pressure wit

media.description:
Stemming from conversations about Japanese clear ice ball makers with Brad Kohlmeyer I'm compelled to try methods to create clear ice and form ice into shapes using pressure.

Here are some of the materials used in this round of experiments:
Large Styrofoam drink cups
Diet coke cans
Electric pump and straws
Film canister full of pennies (not pictured)
3D printed golf ball form (not pictured)
Extruded aluminum beam (not pictured)
40lb of weights (not pictured)
media.title: 20150907_160957.jpg

media.description: Electrical connection between 7v adapter and motor double sealed in heat shrink as it will be submerged.
media.title: 20150907_161854.jpg

media.description: Pump immersed in water
media.title: 20150907_161902.jpg

media.description: Blurry picture of pump running under water, note the water is flowing gently and not spraying everywhere.
media.title: 20150907_162037.jpg

media.description: The Diet Coke can has it's top cut off, and the drink lid is cut to hold the inverted soda can.
media.title: 20150907_162455.jpg

media.description: The aluminum can will be exposed to the frigid air while the water will be somewhat insulated in the cup for a while.
media.title: 20150907_162637.jpg

media.description: Water pump spraying water into the inverted aluminum can in front of the freezer blower experiment.
media.title: 20150907_162911.jpg

media.description:
Three hours later...
No significant amount of ice in the can, but the straw froze solid and the surface of the water in the cup began to freeze.
Not a success.

I *think* for this to work, I need to recirculate water over the can which needs to be aggressively heat synced to the condenser coils in the freezer.
media.title: 20150907_193951.jpg

media.description: Water frozen in straw.
media.title: 20150907_194011.jpg

media.description:
Try the Japanese pond method.
The ice is white from bubbles trapped inside, the story goes that water frozen slowly from above will not capture bubbles in the first several inches and will freeze clear.

To do this I'll freeze water in the can inside the drinking glass.  I'm putting holes in the bottom of the can to relieve pressure and let water flow out of the can as the sheet of ice thickens.
media.title: 20150907_194318.jpg

media.description: Empty cup
media.title: 20150907_194600.jpg

media.description: Add soda can which rests conveniently on raised structures in the bottom of the cup.
media.title: 20150907_194606.jpg

media.description: The can is not all the way in the bottom of the cup and is only in contact in 3 places, water can flow around the can.
media.title: 20150907_194629.jpg

media.description: Full of un filtered, un boiled, tap water.
media.title: 20150907_194806.jpg

media.description: Sealed in the cup for slow freezing.
media.title: 20150907_194824.jpg

media.description: Two experiments in the freezer, one has holes in the can, one doesn't
media.title: 20150908_094504.jpg

media.description: This looks promising
media.title: 20150908_094520.jpg

media.description: I did try to use the 3D printed golf ball mold with regular white freezer ice cubes and weights to form the ice into a golf ball.  The ice is below the plastic container in the metal can below the 40lbs of dumbbells.
media.title: 20150908_130353.jpg

media.description: Earlier the 40lbs cracked the 3D printed mold, but I still can use it if I press directly on the top of the ball.
media.title: 20150908_133757.jpg

media.description:
Not ideal.
It was shrinking and forming but it stopped.  
I think it stopped because eventually the pressure spread out so that the pressure per surface area got below the regelation point.  
Also, the plastic got cold and could not conduct more heat to the surface to aid in melting and forming.
media.title: 20150908_133835.jpg

media.description: Remember the can with holes and the one without?
media.title: 20150908_154622.jpg

media.description:
To remove the cans from the cups I inverted them in a plastic container in front of a fan.  Sooner or later they warm up, melt a little at the ice-cup interface and PLUNK! drop out into the plastic container.

Interesting!

They are both cloudy, but the can without the holes on the left has trail shaped bubbles from where ice could not form around air bubbles and they were pushed down in the process.
media.title: 20150908_163031.jpg

media.description: Ice cap at the bottom of the cup containing the can with the holes in it
media.title: 20150908_163221.jpg

media.description: Ice cap at the bottom of the cup containing the can with the holes in it
media.title: 20150908_163229.jpg

media.description:
The top of the ice that formed in the can.
I believe this proves that it can work in theory, but I don't know what to change to get a larger clear area of ice.
media.title: 20150908_163331.jpg

media.description:
The top of the ice that formed in the can.
I believe this proves that it can work in theory, but I don't know what to change to get a larger clear area of ice.

You can also just make out one or more shells of fine bubbles in the clear area.
media.title: 20150908_163348.jpg

media.description:
The bottom caps of the two.
On the left the one without holes in the can, containing bubble trails.
On the right the one without bubble trails from the can without holes in it.
media.title: 20150908_163445.jpg

media.description: About to remove the ice core from the can without holes in the bottom.
media.title: 20150908_163454.jpg

media.description: The Japanese pond thing worked here too but the cloudiness reaches much higher.
media.title: 20150908_163604.jpg

media.description: Here is an old film canister
media.title: 20150908_163803.jpg

media.description: Filled with pennies
media.title: 20150908_163934.jpg

media.description:
Used to raise the can up higher in the glass, farther from the edges.

I've added another hole in the center of the bottom of the can.
media.title: 20150908_164050.jpg

media.description: I took this piece of extruded aluminum, placed it on one of the chunks of ice from the bottom of the glass and put pressure on it to see how pressure on aluminum would regelate the ice.
media.title: 20150908_170042.jpg

media.description: Note the areas in the hexagonal and round hole where the ice remained
media.title: 20150908_170106.jpg

media.description: Note how well the shape was preserved.
media.title: 20150908_170115.jpg

media.description: Here you can see the extruded aluminum shape through the ice
media.title: 20150908_170143.jpg

media.description: Once again, note how well the shape is captured, including the interior hexagonal and circular holes.
media.title: 20150908_170156.jpg

media.description: Left it under pressure until it came through the bottom.
media.title: 20150908_170207.jpg

media.description: All the way pressed in.
media.title: 20150908_170300.jpg

media.description: Nice detail, even ridges on the outer surface were captured in cross section.
media.title: 20150908_170308.jpg

media.description: I thought I'd try degassing hot tap water under vacuum
media.title: 20150909_203232.jpg

media.description: Pulling a vacuum, -75kpa, -11psi and the water started to bubble on the surface of the container, but my vacuum chamber was leaky (bubbles in background are from soap water test on the base outside the chamber) and I couldn't get down to a nice room temperature rolling boil.
media.title: 20150909_203243.jpg

media.description: More bubbles, but no rolling boil.
media.title: 20150909_203327.jpg

media.description:
Results of penny jar freeze of unfiltered, unboiled tap water.
It's really hard to see but I froze this one a cup within a cup for added insulation, you can see the bottom outer cup at the bottom of this image.
media.title: 20150909_204129.jpg

media.description: The inner cup burst at the bottom.
media.title: 20150909_204224.jpg

media.description: I don't know if its related to the water trapped under the film canister of pennies, or as I suspect, simply that one cup was suspended inside another and didn't have the back pressure of the freezer bottom pushing back up on the bottom of the cup.
media.title: 20150909_204235.jpg

media.description: Ice plug around the can and film canister contains some bubbles but not the bubble streaks in the first experiment without holes in the can.
media.title: 20150909_210701.jpg

media.description: Looks pretty good inside.
media.title: 20150909_210716.jpg

media.description:
The bottom of the ice within the can.  
There are interesting wood grain looking features in the ice surface...
suggesting  freezing the last bit in waves maybe?
media.title: 20150909_211017.jpg

media.description: OK results, similar to predecessors, with a little more clear area but wait...
media.title: 20150909_211030.jpg

media.description: There are really interesting shells of white caused by trapped fine bubbles.
media.title: 20150909_211106.jpg

media.description:
Turned about 90 degrees
Shells of fine misty bubbles
media.title: 20150909_211114.jpg

media.description:
Shells of fine misty bubbles
very curious.
media.title: 20150909_211345.jpg

media.description:
Shells of fine misty bubbles
I thought about this for a long time
media.title: 20150909_211358.jpg

media.description:
I finally came to the conclusion these are the on off cycles of the compressor and fan in the freezer.
I assume the white sections are formed when the ice gets too cold, perhaps the expansion causes higher pressure squeezing gasses out of solution.

Anyway, each one of these Japanese pond style ice cores takes 24 hours to make.  I know that commercial ice makers circulate near freezing filtered water over very cold metal forms to grow clear ice as it forms in icicles.  This can be done quickly and reliably and future experiments are likely to return to similar methods.
media.title: 20150909_211413.jpg
